text: now we have had the latest data on the us economy 's robust service industries , here is a mid-afternoon summary .
surging demand in the uk services industry has led to an increase in hiring , and raised expectations of a rise in interest rates .

spain and germany have also seen a flood of new business activity , boosting employment rolls france 's services industries managed to grow in july , but decline in manufacturing makes it the laggard among eurozone economies the chief executive of credit agricole reported a €708m ( £ 562m ) loss over its exposure to banco espirito santo the bank of england 's chief economist has said regulatory fine-tuning could become a permanent job for central bankers , in a post-crash financial system with more risk emanating from insurance companies , mutuals and pension funds .
that 's all from the business blog today .
thank you for following and commenting .

us service industries continued growing in july , but fell back slightly on the previous month .
the markit purchasing managers ' index came in at 60.8 in july , making this the 9th consecutive month the survey was above the growth benchmark of 50 .
the july figure was slightly below expectations that the index would remain at the june level of 61 .
higher levels of work contributed to more hiring , although the pace of job creation slackened compared to the previous month .
chris williamson , chief economist at markit , said the survey suggested the us economy was maintaining strong momentum , but warned that growth could cool .
the elevated survey readings suggest that the economy is on course to grow strongly again in the third quarter , building on the 4.0 % annualised expansion of gdp seen in the second quarter .
this is also a broad-based upturn : the services sector grew at a rapid pace , just slightly weaker than june 's post-recession high , accompanied by a surge in factory production .
however , there are signs that growth could cool in coming months .
the surveys indicate that the rate of job creation has waned , as have inflows of new business .
business confidence has also fallen to the lowest since late 2012 as companies have noted greater economic uncertainty and mounting risk aversion .
while the economy looks set to continue to expand at robust pace in the second half of the year , these summer months may turn out to represent the peaking in the rate of growth .
wall street stocks have opened slightly down , largely in line with expectations following data from china that showed declining growth in service industries .
the dow jones is down 0.35 % at 16,510 points , while the nasdaq is down 0.4 % at 4366 points .
the final tranche of today 's major economic data is due at 14.45 uk time , when we have the us service managers ' purchasing index .
a preliminary reading showed the index at 61 for july , unchanged from june , which was the highest reading since the survey began in october 2009 .

he was speaking the day after russian budget airline dobrolet announced it was cancelling all flights , because of eu sanctions .
almost 30,000 russian holidaymakers were left stranded when another tour company cancelled operations .
medvedev also said russia may have to raise taxes as a last resort to deal with the west 's punitive action .

delving a little deeper into the latest french economic data shows how entrenched the problems are .
french service industries grew in july , to reach 50.4 on markit 's purchasing managers ' index , an advance on 48.2 in june and good news from a survey when anything over 50 counts as expansion .
but the details are not so encouraging : employment in service industries fell for the 9th successive month , although the pace of job losses began to ease .

documents.title: how central banks have reinvented themselves
text: the bank of england has published the full text of chief economist andrew haldane 's article for the central banking journal .
the bank of england .

devlin/pa and it is well worth reading , not least for a very good overview of how central banks evolved from the ethos of never apologise , never explain '' into independent institutions in the public eye .
haldane explains how central banks had to re-invent themselves during the financial crisis .
on monetary policy , we have gone from setting short safe rates to shaping rates of return on longer-term and wider classes of assets .
on regulation , central banks have gone from spectator to player , with some granted micro-prudential as well as macro-prudential regulatory responsibilities .
on operational matters , central banks have gone from market-watcher to market-shaper and market-maker across a broad class of assets and counterparties .
on transparency , we have gone from blushing introvert to blooming extrovert .
central banks are unlikely to return to those pre-crisis days .
in this world , central banks ' operational policies would be likely to remain expansive .
non-bank counterparties would grow in importance , not shrink .
so too , potentially , would more exotic forms of collateral taken in central banks ' operations .

market-making , in a wider class of financial instruments , could become a more standard part of the central bank toolkit , to mitigate the effects of temporary market illiquidity droughts in the non-bank sector .
we also learn that haldane is an a.a milne fan .
the article is titled halfway up the stairs and quotes milne 's 1924 poem , halfway down .

documents.title: moody 's downgrades uk banking outlook
text: moody 's have blamed regulation and misconduct investigations for their decision to downgrade the outlook for the uk banking system .
here is the statement from carlos suarez duarte , a moody 's vice president .

the key driver of the change in outlook to negative for the uk banking system is that the uk government is now able to finalise the secondary legislation to implement the structural reforms relating to the uk resolution and bail-in regime and the related ring-fencing framework .
banks are facing regulations designed to prevent a rerun of the financial crisis , including setting up a ringfence between their retail banking and casino '' investment arms .
on monday hsbc chairman douglas flint attempted to sound a churchillian note , as he complained about unprecedented '' regulatory reforms .
i do not think we have ever had to ask so much of so many the demands now being placed on the human capital of the firm and on our operational and systems capabilities are unprecedented .
that makes the timing of this moody 's downgrade especially interesting .

another factor in the downgrade decision was uk banks ' exposure to conduct and litigation charges that moody 's deem likely to hit profits but moody 's , which along with the other ratings agencies faced criticism for failing to spot the financial crash , thinks uk banks are mostly in a good place the improved credit fundamentals of most uk banks - mainly asset quality , earnings and capital - put them in a stronger position to withstand unexpected shocks , such as a house price correction .

documents.title: expert views on interest rates
text: will interest rates go up before the election ?
that is one of the big questions preoccupying economists .
and today 's data showing strong growth in the uk services sector will only heighten expectations .
here is a round-up of economists ' reaction to the pmi data : howard archer , uk economist at ihs , describes the services industry data as a significantly stronger report than expected '' .

not only was the headline services business activity index at an eight-month high in july , but other elements of the survey were largely very strong which bodes very well for services activity through the third quarter and beyond .

he thinks this boost the chances of a rate rise : with governor mark carney stressing that the strength of data will drive when the bank of england will first edge up interest rates , the overall robust set of july purchasing managers ' surveys with strong incoming new business will likely be seen as supportive to a move in late-2014 rather than early-2015 .
james knightley at ing also thinks a few members of the bank of england 's monetary policy committee will be minded to vote for a rate rise after reading this report .

[ the july reading ] suggests that the uk economy is maintaining its momentum in 3q14 and will increase speculation that one , possibly two members of the bank of england 's mpc will be voting for a rate rise at thursday 's policy meeting .

the slightly disappointing aspect of the report is that the expectations component has fallen to an eight month low , but this is no real surprise given the pace of recent expansion and the fact that sterling strength and the prospect of interest rate rises are potential headwinds .
jeremy cook , chief economist at currency company world first , sees signs of commendable strength '' in the uk economy .

job creation has continued the trend of improvement seen through the first half of the year , something that will only extend , given the rise in work backlogs hitting a 7 month high.this will eventually show in wage settlements , although those remain low and stable at the moment .

sector strength was seen domestically and , more importantly , internationally , which stands in contrast to current thoughts from corporates in the manufacturing sector that the recent strength of the pound may be damaging british businesses ' prospects abroad .
another forecast from chris williamson of markit : chris williamson ( @ williamsonchris ) uk pmi employment index still elevated in july .
signals c+100k jobs .
unemployment likely to drop below 6 % by year end
chris williamson , chief economist at markit , is forecasting a 0.8 % rise in gdp for the third quarter if current trends continue .
the vast services economy 's growth surge shows no sign of abating .
the july pmi showed the sector expanding at the fastest rate since last november , as demand for services continued to increase at a rate rarely seen in the survey 's 18-year history .
the buoyancy of the services and construction sector pmis suggest the domestic economy clearly continued to boom in july , offsetting the cooling of growth seen in the manufacturing sector .
so what is behind the uptick in services activity ?
purchasing managers told markit they had been hiring more people , to keep on top of current workloads and in anticipation of more in the coming months .
backlogs of work were increasing , although positive sentiment about the future was lower than in previous months .
companies also said wages were driving up operating costs .
the markit/cips purchasing managers index for services rose to 59.1 in july , up from 57.7 in june , well clear of the benchmark of 50 that signals expansion .
over 30 % of the survey panel reported an increase in activity since june .

documents.title: more bad news from france
text: eurozone economic growth accelerated in july , on the back of an uptick in business in germany and spain .
but bad news in france , where a slight in services was offset by deepening downturn for manufacturing .
markit 's eurozone composite output index rose to a three-month high of 53.8 in july , up from 52.8 in june .

here is the full breakdown : germany 55.7 spain 55.7 italy 53.1 france 49.4 the country-by-country underscores the weakness in france ; on this markit scale anything less than 50 means the economy is shrinking .
the financial crisis has changed economic policy making for good .

that could be one conclusion to draw from the bank of england 's chief economist andrew haldane , who has said central banks would find it difficult to beat an orderly retreat '' from regulating the financial system .
in an article in the journal central banking , haldane said central banks could have a permanent role in the regulatory fine-tuning of banks and other financial institutions .
it is likely that regulatory policy would need to be in a constant state of alert for risks emerging in the financial shadows , which could trip up regulators and the financial system .
in other words , regulatory fine-tuning could become the rule , not the exception .
haldane also warned of new risks facing the financial system , as a result of potentially risky activity from mutual funds , insurance companies and pension funds .

[ the financial system could ] exhibit a new strain of systemic risk - a greater number of higher-frequency , higher-amplitude cyclical fluctuations in asset prices and financial activity , now originating on the balance sheets of mutual funds , insurance companies and pension funds these cyclical fluctuations could in turn be transmitted to , and mirrored , in greater cyclical instabilities in the wider economy .
the highlights are summarised on centralbanking.com .
i will try and track down a full copy of the text .

a surge in new orders provided a real boost to the spanish service sector in july , leading to a faster rise in activity and further job creation .
companies remained optimistic that these recent improvements will continue over the coming year .

firms still had to lower their output prices in order to achieve the sort of new business growth recorded in july , but the rate of discounting was the least marked since the economic crisis began in mid-2008 .
spanish service providers saw new business increase at the sharpest pace since late-2006 in july , buoyed by a strong demand for transport and financial services .

documents.title: tuesday 's events : global services in focus
text: good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy , the financial markets , the eurozone and the business world .
spain is growing , italy slowing and france is stagnating .
germany remains solid , while the uk is showing healthy growth .
that is what economists are expecting from a batch of data on services that will fill in more details about the health of european economies .
the uk data is likely to show that services , which make up three quarters of the economy , are in robust condition .
economists have pencilled in a reading of 58.1 , up from june 's 57.7 , on the markit purchasing managers ' index where anything over 50 counts as expansion .
in france the reading is expected to come in at 50.4 , putting further pressure on president françois hollande .

michael hewson of cmc markets sums it up today 's numbers may paint a positive in some areas , namely spain where gdp appears to be recovering slowly , but france remains a particular concern , with rising unemployment and an economy mired in quicksand , and a paralysed government .
it is a very different story in china , where growth in the service sector has fallen to its lowest level in nine years .
the hsbc/markit pmi reading fell to 50.0 in july , the lowest reading since november 2005 when the data series began .

services account for 45 % of china 's economy and the stuttering performance has prompted questions about whether the authorities should do more to support growth , especially in china 's fast-cooling housing market .
aside from data , i 'll be looking at the fallout from the banco espirito santo bailout .
one of the biggest casualties so far is france 's third-largest bank , credit agricole .
the bank announced today it has taken a hit of €708m ( £ 950m ) in relation to is bes stake , wiping out its second quarter profits .
